content.name: title_3
content.content:
Dementia

Information for patients, carers and professionals

content.name: html_1
content.content:
Introduction to the Dementia App

This app is developed for people with dementia and their carers.

Dementia is a life changing condition mostly in later life and is increasingly recognised as an important clinical and social problem with devastating consequences for the patients and those who care for them. Accessing appropriate information and services for people with dementia and their carers is vital in their continuing care and management.

This app development is led by the idea inventor/originator Dr Latha Velayudhan in collaboration with NHS Leicestershire Health Informatics Service (LHIS) and Older Peoples Mental Health Service (OPMH), Oxleas NHS Foundation Trust.

It is intended that the app can be used by people with dementia and their carers at any point or stage of illness so that they can use guidance to help them to manage various aspects of their life and more importantly signpost them to an array of services and organisations that provide specialised support and information, locally, regionally and nationally. There is also information for dementia risk prevention. Signposting information is categorised, such as, finances, transport, employment, living well, relationship etc. with contact details for these resources and links to websites such as Alzheimer's Society, NHS choices and YoungDementia UK.

The dementia app is aimed at patients, families, and health professional alike. The app aims to empower and guidance for self management with appropriate information, knowledge and support following diagnosis.

Project team: Dr Latha Velayudhan (Consultant Psychiatrist, OPMH), Kerry Cyster (LHIS), Gemma Clayton (Business and Marketing Manager, LHIS), Gurtej Brar (Technical Services Manager, LHIS), Ibrahim Pardiwala (Technical Support Specialist, LHIS)

Acknowledgements: We are thankful to Sarah Ost (Service Delivery Manager, LHIS), Dr Abimbole Fadipe (Clinical director, OPMH), Estelle Frost (Service Director, OPMH), Steve Francis (Finance Manager, OPMH) and Alison Furzer (Oxleas Director of Informatics) and Sue Horbury (Oxleas Trust Mobile Application Lead) for facilitating the app development agreement. We are grateful to Eleanor Johnston (Community Manager), Jasmine Martinez (Assistant Psychologist), Mark Saddler (Bromley Dementia hub Manager), Paola Deane (Occupation Therapist), Debby Cutajar (Bromley Memory Service), Dr Sunita Sahu (Consultant Psychiatrist) and Georgina Glass (Health Support Worker) who provided information on local community resources.

We sincerely thank Brian and Mary for the patient and carer video for their perspectives and messages.

Patient and Carer Feedback: We would like to thank Azaad Magho for gathering patient and carer feedback.


Carer - "I easily found all of the information and links I needed, the app is easy to use and navigate"

Patient - "I am a patient in the early stages of dementia and I find the app easy to navigate and found the information useful, If only the app was available when my husband was diagnosed with Dementia"

Dementia
What is it? Find out more
Assessment, Roles and Videos
At Oxleas NHS Foundation Trust
Living with Dementia
Managing aspects of everyday life
Service Directory
Local, regional and national support services

content.name: title_6
content.content: Help

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Tips for using this app


Following links

To access links you will need an internet/mobile data connection from your device. Please be aware that this will use your data allowance if you are connected to 3G/4G internet, so we recommend using the app whilst connected to free WiFi.

Once a link has been accessed it will open in a new window in your default browser.

Phone numbers

If are accessing this app from a mobile phone, touching a phone link will open your phone function with the number to dial.

Email links

Touching an email link will open an email account or choice of email accounts if they are set up on your device. If you do not have any email account(s) set up, then you will probably see a page displaying a list of email providers so you can set one up if you wish.

Maps in the Service Directory

Some Service Directory listings contain a postcode and a map view. Touch the Google logo in the lower left hand side of the map to open in Google maps, either on the browser or in its own app (if it is already installed on your device).

Viewing videos

Videos are in mp4 format and should be playable on most devices. They can be viewed full screen using the expand icon (usually on the far right hand side) on the the play bar at the bottom of the video.

content.name: item_7933222f
content.content: Dementia Assessment, Roles and Videos

content.name: html_1
content.content:
Introduction by Latha Velayudhan - Consultant Psychiatrist, Dementia App project lead

Estelle Frost, OPMH Service Director

Eleanor Johnston, Memory Service Manager

Latha Velayudhan, Consultant psychiatrist, Community Mental Health Team

Abimbole Fadipe, Clinical Director, OPMH and Consultant psychiatrist, dementia ward - Holbrooks

Patient and Carer

Readable Information

Oxleas NHS Foundation Trust Supporting Services

Assessment Information

Dementia assessment is offered as part of Oxleas NHS Foundation Trust Older Peoples Mental health (OPMH). Assessments are carried out in a clinic or home with cognitive impairment and or memory problems, suspected to be due to a progressive neurodegenerative disorder.

People with suspected dementia can be referred by GP or other specialists to the memory services within OPMH, at the Oxleas NHS Foundation Trust. For a person with learning disabilities who may be developing dementia, their GP can make a referral to their local community learning disabilities team for an assessment.

Following assessment and diagnosis, the care of the patients will be transferred to primary care to GP for monitoring of cholinesterase inhibitors, or locality CMHT for further clinical inputs and therapies, if they have progressive dementia.

Those with mild cognitive impairment and non-progressive conditions will be discharged back to their GP. People with any underlying medical or psychiatric disorders other than dementia will be referred back to respective services for further treatment.

Patient Access Points

Memory Services (Bexley)
Bexleyheath Centre
4 Emerton Close
Bexleyheath
Kent
DA6 8DX
United Kingdom

The Memory Service provides assessment, diagnosis and treatment for people who are experiencing difficulties with their memory such as dementia. We tend to see people aged 65 and over, though in some cases we see younger people.

Contact Us:

Phone 020 8301 7900

content.name: title_6
content.content: Dementia

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Dementia is a progressive brain condition characterized by memory loss, difficulties with thinking, problem-solving or language, and an altered ability to cope with basic activities of daily living. Dementia is caused when the brain is damaged by diseases, such as Alzheimer's disease or a series of strokes.

This app aims to provide information and resources for:

  • Anyone concerned that they or a relative or a friend may have got dementia
  • Anyone currently living with dementia
  • Carers, friends or relatives of someone living with dementia
  • Healthcare professionals who wish to understand the support available in Bromley, Bexley and Greenwich boroughs for dementia
  • Anyone who wish to know more about risk factors for dementia and prevention

850,000 people live with dementia in the UK. For statistics on the impact and scale of dementia please see Dementia facts and Alzheimers infographic

Types of dementia

Dementia is an umbrella term. It describes the symptoms that occur when the brain is affected by certain diseases or conditions. There are many different types of dementia although some are far more common than others.


  • Alzheimers disease
  • Vascular dementia
  • Rarer types of dementia
  • Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Frontotemporal dementia

Signs and Symptoms

Symptoms will vary depending on the individual and the type of dementia. The onset of symptoms may be gradual affecting confidence and behaviour. Some of the possible symptoms include:

  • Depression
  • Changes in personality and mood
  • Periods of mental confusion
  • Difficulty finding the right words
  • Problems controlling emotions
  • Loss of empathy - understanding and compassion
  • Planning and organising becomes difficult
  • Social situations become challenging
  • Increasing difficulties with tasks and activities that require concentration and planning
  • Hallucinations
  • Making false claims or statement

Young onset dementia (YOD)

Dementia is considered young onset when it affects people under 65 years of age. This can also be referred to as early onset or working age dementia. Although the symptoms of dementia are similar regardless of age, younger people may have different needs and therefore need different support. About 42,000 people are currently living with YOD in the UK. Further information about YOD can be found on the Alzheimer's Society

Further information about YOD can be found on the Alzheimer's Society Alzheimer's Society and YoungDementia UK websites.

Learning disabilities and dementia

People with learning disabilities, particularly those with Down's syndrome have an increased risk of developing dementia. Studies have shown that almost people with Down's syndrome will develop changes in the brain associated with Alzheimer's disease by the age of 40, however not all will go on the develop clinical symptoms of dementia.

For further information go to Downs Syndrome Association and Alzheimer's Society Learning disabilities and dementia websites.

Mild cognitive impairment

Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) is used to describe people who have some problems with their memory but do not actually have dementia

For further information go to Mild cognitive impairment (MCI)

Dementia prevention

There is no definite way to prevent all types of dementia. Healthy lifestyle, however, can lower risk of some types of dementia and overall health can benefit from these strategies. Keeping mind active and body fit may help to protect brain against mental decline and reduce or postpone memory loss.


  • Risk factors for dementia
  • How to reduce your risk of dementia
  • Alcohol
  • Smoking
  • Exercises
  • Diet
  • Brain training
  • Can dementia be prevented?

content.name: title_6
content.content: Living with Dementia

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Being diagnosed with dementia does not mean stopping things you enjoy, however it may be that you have to do them in a different way. The sections below provide tips and resources to support you to live as well as possible. In addition to this information the Alzheimers Society has a range of helpful factsheets

Living Well
Emotional Impact
Relationships
Health and Wellbeing
Working
Driving and Travel
Finances
Activities

content.name: title_6
content.content: About

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Oxleas NHS Foundation Trust

Oxleas NHS Foundation Trust provide local NHS services in south London and Kent that take care of the whole person - body and mind.

Oxleas NHS Foundation Trust provide a wide range of health and social care services in south east London, specialising in community health, mental health and learning disability services. The trust has a workforce of around 3,500 people including many highly skilled health and social care professionals. The Trust has over 125 sites in a variety of locations across the London Boroughs of Bexley, Bromley and Greenwich and into Kent.

Visit our value page to watch a short film to see Oxleas Trust improving lives through innovation and quality in health and social care.

Find out more at http://oxleas.nhs.uk/

Follow us on Twitter @OxleasNHS

Leicestershire Health Informatics Service (LHIS)

The NHS Leicestershire Health Informatics Service (LHIS) is a mature Information Management & Technology (IM&T) provider employing over 130 members of staff, supporting customer organisations across the UK with IT services and tailored IT solutions. Find out more about what LHIS can do for you at www.leics-his.nhs.uk.


Follow us on Twitter @LeicsHis



Commontime

CommonTime are a leading provider of mobile technology for the healthcare sector. Find out more about what Commontime can do for you at www.commontime.com.

Follow us on Twitter @CT_Healthcare

content.name: title_6
content.content: Living Well

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Supporting those living with dementia are approximately over 700,000 informal carers and a wide range of agencies, charities and organisations that are there to provide support, care and guidance. The Department of Health estimate that 59 percent of people with dementia in England have a formal diagnosis.

The information in this section of the app combined with the service directory aims to provide tips and information to support getting the most out of life and help with adapting to changes as they occur

Follow this link to the NHS Choices video where an expert explains about the value of various activities such as singing and patients sharing their experiences. There is also information on how to live well and independently with dementia.

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e
content.content:
• Home
  • Help
  • About
  • Terms
  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Emotional Impact

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Being told that you or someone close to you has been diagnosed with dementia is a major thing and will impact emotionally with potentially confusing emotions. This is a normal and understandable response to the changes you are dealing with.

Things that may help you include:

  • Talking to a friend or family member
  • Ask for help from one of the many support services available (see our service directory for these)
  • Trying to ensure you still do the things you enjoy in life to support you and your wellbeing
  • Accepting there is no right or wrong way to feel and that it will take time to work through the emotions you are experiencing

Beyond the initial diagnosis, living with dementia can lead to experiencing changes and swings in mood with feelings of sadness, anger, fear or frustration as the disease progresses.

For family and friends it can be difficult to stay positive. It is important to remember you are not alone and that help and support is available. Sharing your worries or concerns can help be it with a family member, friend, GP or support group.

Alzheimer's Society has advice on understanding and caring for someone with dementia, with tips on how carers can look after themselves too

There is also information for carers, friends and relatives of people with dementia, on how to cope with feelings of grief.

YoungDementia UK has advice on explaining to family and friends and also on telling children about a young onset dementia diagnosis. There is also advice on who else to tell.

Alzheimer's research UK website Dementia explained helps children and teenagers understand dementia, how it affects someone and how it could impact their lives.

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e
content.content:
• Home
  • Help
  • About
  • Terms
  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Relationships

content.name: html_2
content.content:
For those living with or caring for someone with dementia it is important to keep an active social life maintaining contact with others. For those living with dementia this will help keep them active and stimulated.

It can be difficult for people to talk about their own or a family members dementia or people may want to help but dont know how to. In this case it is important where possible to not lose touch. Often this may mean having to make the first move explaining that you need to see them and how they can help.

Many support groups exist and although many people can be put off by the idea of joining a group the opportunity to be part of a community of people with dementia or a group of families who have a member with dementia can be helpful. Often this can provide sharing of experiences, insights, useful information and tips from others who are going through or have been through similar situations.

The Alzheimers Society has relationship information and advice here.

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e
content.content:
• Home
  • Help
  • About
  • Terms
  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Health and Wellbeing

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Health

Living healthily is important for everyone, including those with dementia. Poor health through diet and/or lifestyle has been proven to increase the risk of developing dementia.

Having a healthy lifestyle, eating well and exercising will contribute to overall quality of life and support emotional wellbeing. Changes in eating habits can occur and it is important to maintain regular meals to avoid weight loss and poor nutrition.

The Live Well section of NHS Choices has health and wellbeing information and advice for everyone.

NHS Choices Live Well links

Here are some links to the Live Well section of the NHS Choices website that you may find helpful and inspiring:


  • All Topics
  • Exercise
  • Food and diet
  • Sleep
  • Living with a condition
  • Stop smoking

Tap the button below to access more details of organisations and services that specialise in health and well-being.


Healthcare links and organisations

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e
content.content:
• Home
  • Help
  • About
  • Terms
  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Working

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Many people are still able to work after being diagnosed with dementia. Continuing to work can support self-esteem, keep the brain active, provide income and support maintaining an active social life. Where there is stress and anxiety with struggling to continue working Occupational Therapy (OT) can become involved to support maintaining employment.

Timing about informing an employer is down to the individual to decide though it is important to check if there is a requirement to inform the employer about changes that could impact on safety at work or if driving forms part of the job. Disclosure to an employer should lead to gaining legal rights and support.

The Alzheimers Society has an employment booklet with further information.

Your rights

Dementia is a disability as defined in the Equality Act 2010. This is due to it being a long term condition that lasts more than 12 months and has an effect on normal day to day activity.

The Act requires employers to avoid discrimination and make reasonable adjustments to ensure people with dementia are not disadvantaged in the workplace. Reasonable adjustments might include changes to working hours, part time working, aids or equipment to support doing a job.

  • The government has more general information here: GOV.UK
  • The Dementia Engagement and Empowerment Project (DEEP) has published a guide for employers who would like to be more dementia friendly, to download it follow this link: GOV.UK - DEEP Guide - Tips for employers
  • Employers are also obliged to consider requests for flexible working from carers under the Flexible Working Regulations (2006): YoungDementia UK Information on Working & Volunteering

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e
content.content:
• Home
  • Help
  • About
  • Terms
  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Driving and Travel

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Can I still drive?

The DVLA (Driving Vehicle Licencing Authority) can provide an assessment to determine if someone diagnosed with dementia can continue driving. The DVLA has a form which is used to provide information and if this turns out to be difficult to fill out then a friend or family member may be able to help.

Following this an assessment may be requested and if the DVLA decides that it is safe to continue driving then a new license will be issued for a limited period with a regular follow up review required. If it is decided by the DVLA that driving has to stop then it is possible to appeal the decision and the DVLA website has information on this.

Does it matter when I do it?

It is important to notify the DVLA and your insurer immediately after a diagnosis of dementia as it can potentially invalidate insurance and lead to a fine of up to ÃÂ£1,000.

Insurance

It is illegal to drive without valid insurance in the UK and someone close may be able to talk to the insurers on your behalf if you are not able to do so personally.

Tips and ideas

If you can carry on driving it might help to only drive on routes that are well known to you or on quieter roads with less traffic. It may also help to have a passenger accompany you for your journey.

As with any driving it is important to not drive when tired as this can be dangerous and make the experience more stressful. It is wise to pullover if starting to feel unwell or confused.

Alternatives

It can feel as though independence has been lost for those no longer able to drive or when the time comes that it is no longer possible. However there are alternatives available to restore the sense of freedom and independence and enable travel. Taxis, lifts from friends/ family and public transport can enable travel without driving.

Bus Passes

It may well be that you are entitled to a free bus pass.

  • Throughout England and wales a free bus pass is available to eligible disabled people and those over 60 in England and Wales.
  • Disabled people and people over 60 are entitled to free bus travel anywhere in Scotland with a National Entitlement Card.

Train travel

  • Discount railcards are available which can reduce fares by up to a third for yourself and a companion.
  • Many companies offer travel assistance to help with boarding a train and to provide advice at the end of the journey.

Taxi

  • Setting up an account with a local taxi company can be useful as it saves worrying about having money to hand.
  • If a taxi driver is particularly understanding and helpful it may be useful to request that driver each time, particularly when travelling alone.
  • Some local councils have a taxi scheme offering free or reduced taxi travel for people with dementia.

Useful Links

  • www.disabledpersons-railcard.co.uk

  • www.gov.uk/dementia-and-driving

Transport and travel links and organisations

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e
content.content:
• Home
  • Help
  • About
  • Terms
  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Finances

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Dementia may well affect income and financial commitments. This might include giving up work earlier than planned which could have a considerable impact if there are dependants or significant financial commitments.

Even if you are on top of your finances and managing them well it is always good to plan ahead and it is often cheaper to have procedures in place early on for managing your finances.

Tap the button below this list to investigate these considerations:

  • Bank Accounts
  • Lasting power of attorney - GOV.UK information
  • Making a Will
  • Pensions and retirement
  • Benefits
  • Grants
  • Paying for care and support

Finance and benefit links and organisations

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e
content.content:
• Home
  • Help
  • About
  • Terms
  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Activities

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Being diagnosed with dementia should not mean an end to the things that you enjoy and stop you living a full life. To achieve this and live well with dementia will mean adapting to the changes as they occur.

Some things that may be of help can include:

  • Building up a support network of family, friends, groups and organisations who can provide reassurance and support
  • Socialising, exercise and eating a healthy diet
  • Equipment, electronic reminders and adaptions can help to make the home safer and support independence
  • Technologies such as Skype and FaceTime can support communications and keeping in touch

It is important to continue to enjoy hobbies and interests bearing in mind that activities may need to change over time as the illness progresses. It is important to remember that those living with dementia can and should enjoy their spare time.

There are number of local and regional programmes to facilitate various activities

Age UK Bromley & Greenwich runs the Fit for Life for people aged 50 and above. It is a 12-week programme that covers exercise, healthy eating, learning and leisure, sexual health, social interaction, staying well, spirituality and well-being. They are also running Chair based exercise classes

Bromley Mencapoffers a range of activities including the Outdoors Activity Club, Discos, workshops and Keep Fitclasses.

Get Active Londonhas over 13,000 ways to get active! Visit their website now and search for hundreds of activities in your area from Aerobics to football, wrestling to belly dancing.

There are walking groups, Bromley Walk for Life and cycling groups for wellbeing, Wheels for Wellbeing

Activities and leisure links and organisations

content.name: item_ea345a2e

• Home

  • Terms
  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Oxleas NHS Foundation Trust Supporting Services

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Older People's Mental Health Services
Memory Service
Advanced Care Planning: Planning for the future
Living well with dementia workshop
Living well
Carers and cared for drop in
Therapeutic activity group
Oxleas dementia strategy 2013-2016
Understanding memory difficulties
Useful organisations for rarer types of dementia

Supporting Services

Oxleas NHS Foundation Trust offers a wide array of services. The services listed above are ones which more commonly might be accessed by someone living with dementia. You can also look up the details for all of our services plus a wide range of community services in the boroughs of Bexley, Bromley and Greenwich and some national services.
For futher information please visit: http://oxleas.nhs.uk/services/

Older Peoples Mental Health Service

We offer a range of services for older people with mental health needs living in Bexley, Bromley and Greenwich. Our Community Mental Health Team services for older people offer both assessment and therapy, Memory Clinics investigate patient's memory problems and our Inpatient Services offer care and assessment for a full range of mental health conditions including dementia. The other services include Intensive Home Treatment Team, Liaison Psychiatry services and Care Home Project teams to assess, support and treat people in community, general hospitals and care homes within the locality. We sometimes see younger people if their needs might be best met by our service.


Our services include: Inpatient services
Our wards care for the most vulnerable patients during periods of acute mental illness and when they are too unwell to be cared for in the community. Scadbury ward is based at Green Park House near the Princess Royal University Hospital and Holbrook ward is based at the Queen Mary's Hospital.
Holbrook ward specialise in assessment and care of patients with dementia, see Dementia Services

How can you access our services?

  • Speak to your GP
  • Speak to any other healthcare professional involved in your care

Who do our teams include?

Who is who - roles in health and social services

Memory Service

The Memory Service is hosted in the Older People's service which also sees younger people with memory difficulties.
It is designed to provide you with information about memory problems, living well, support, services available and practical issues. You may or may not have a diagnosis of dementia. If you have been seen in our memory service the clinician will have tailored an information pack for you.

You can find further information at the following link:

Advanced Care Planning: Planning for the future

Being told that you may have dementia can be a scary thing, but there are a lot of good things to share and discuss as well as some things that you can do to plan for the future. In many ways, everyone should think through these things, but at the time of diagnosis it is a good idea to revisit important decisions.

You can find further information at the following link:

Living well with dementia workshop

Since the establishment of the Memory Service within Bromley, we have been getting better at diagnosing more people with dementia and earlier on. However, patients and families told us that they wanted more support from services following the diagnosis. A workshop was therefore proposed as a way of providing information and support to a large group of people in an accessible manner. The workshop had the following aims:

  • to provide some basic information on what dementia is
  • to provide an alternative, person centred view of dementia
  • to provide some useful coping strategies for coping with the impact dementia can have on relationships and functioning
  • to signpost to other services and sources of information in the borough.

You can find further information at the following link:

Living well

It is possible to live well with dementia. Many people continue to maintain important aspects of their lives with supportive strategies. Living well with dementia is about understanding your needs and letting people around you know what you find supportive. Maintaining a sense of wellbeing comes from communicating with each other as the symptoms change. As the dementia progresses your support will need to adapt to your needs.

The Oxleas memory service has three teams (Bexley, Bromley, Greenwich), which focus on assessment and brief intervention for people with significant difficulties. There are also many charities, services and organisations in these three boroughs which offer support and advice. There are lots of support networks for people who are living with a dementia.

You can find further information at the following link:

Carers and cared for drop in

Service users and carers of people with dementia runs every 2nd Tuesday of every month. 10.30-12.00

The service provides practical information and support for carer's occasional speakers on topics relevant to caring role. Peer Support. Socialising and reminiscence for the person with dementia

You can find further information at the following link:

Therapeutic activity group

We have introduced a therapeutic activity programme for our dementia services which includes a variety of groups such as singing, dancing, gardening and baking. Activities are purpose based, not simply for entertainment.

We have three key strategies - person centred care, falls prevention and cognitive rehabilitation.

  • Person centred care - we work with patients, families and carers, getting to know people. One example is our weekly afternoon tea, which helps patients get to know each other and form friendships.
  • Falls prevention - activities include music and movement, circle dancing, exercise, nature walks and gardening. Twice weekly physiotherapy is also available.
  • Cognitive rehabilitation - provides mental stimulation, aids recall, stimulates function, and is used instead of drugs. Examples of activities are our Reminiscence sessions - used to help people recall memories, cognitive stimulation therapy and 'Terrace Chat' which is football focused, where people can recount experiences through the use of football memorabilia such as old programmes, hats, scarves, etc. Daily Sparkle is a reminiscence newspaper produced regularly.

You can find further information at the following link:

Oxleas dementia strategy 2013-2016

You can find further information at the following link:

Understanding memory difficulties

Firstly, it is important to acknowledge that no one has a perfect memory. In fact everyone's memory can be affected by:

  • certain illnesses such as infections
  • feeling very worried or very low
  • side effects from certain medications
  • tiredness
  • normal ageing process

These influences can either be treated and therefore any memory problems should improve or they will only cause mild memory difficulties.

Memory difficulties are more concerning when they start to prevent a person being able to complete everyday tasks. Sometimes this is due to a specific memory problem that is not caused by one of the factors above.

You can find further information at the following link:

Useful organisations for rarer types of dementia

You can find further information at the following link:

content.name: title_6
content.content: Assessment Information

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Video transcripts

The following sections expand to give an overview of roles and responsibilities of those involved with a patient from diagnosis and also a patient's account of how he tries to live his life as positively as possible.

Introduction by Project Lead

Hello, my name is Latha. Welcome to the Dementia App which is aimed at people with dementia, their carers, families, friends and also other professionals who wish to know more about the condition and also support available, locally, regionally and nationally. We have tried to collate as much information and links to benefit everyone.

We would greatly appreciate feedback and comments to improve it further. Thank you. See Contact us page

Service Director

Hello, my name is Estelle and I'm the Service Director of the Oxleas Older Peoples Mental Health Directorate.

One of the services that we provide is for people with dementia. We receive around 250 new referrals every month for people with suspected dementia who come into our service for assessment and diagnosis. We know that many of those people will be able to go on to lead fulfilling lives with the support of their families and sometimes with extra support from ourselves in the Health Service.

Some people will need even more support and we have a range of services that can help people to continue to live at home including intensive home treatment within the home. For people who are really finding it a struggle at home, we also have an in-patient ward on the Queen Marys Hospital site called Holbrook Ward, where people who are experiencing real difficulties can come and receive support and support for families as well.

Community Manager

Hello, my name is Eleanor and I am an Community Manager.

We provide assessment and dementia diagnosis in the Memory Service in the boroughs of Bromley, Bexley and Greenwich. The Memory Service comprises of; Psychiatrists, Memory nurses, Psychologists, Occupational Therapists and Support Workers.

Referrals to the Memory Service are usually made by a person's GP. Following assessment if the person is diagnosed with dementia they maybe started on anti-dementia medication. If this is the case the medication will be started and they will be followed up by the Memory Nurse. If medication is not appropriate we can provide occupational therapy or psychology input as well as group work.

We provide everyone with information about support services in their area.

When we have established diagnosis and have provided the appropriate treatment we will transfer you back to the care of your GP. If the diagnosis is mild cognitive impairment we will recall you in one year to review your situation and if things remain the same we will transfer you back to the GP letting them know that they can re-refer you if there are any further concerns. If a person develops behavioural or psychological problems we would refer them to the Community Mental Health Team for ongoing support.

Consultant Psychiatrist

Hello, my name is Latha and I am a Consultant Psychiatrist in the Community Mental Health Team,

Community Mental Health Team for Older People at each borough of Bromley, Bexley and Greenwich provides assessments, management and support for people who develop behavioural and psychological symptoms with dementia.

The team consists of Psychiatrists, Psychologists, Social Workers, Support Workers, Mental Health Nurses and Occupational Therapists.

The help provided includes, medications, social stimulation, carer support, help with day to day activities and liaising with other professionals and specialists for any further management that is required.

The patients are seen in their own homes, care homes or in out-patient clinics as appropriate or convenient.

Consultant

Hello, my name is Abi, Im the Consultant on our Dementia Intensive Care Unit.

As dementia progresses, some people develop behavioural symptoms associated with this and they need care in a specialist in-patient unit, which is what we provide on Holbrook.

Holbrook is a ward which has been designed to alleviate the distress associated with these behaviours. The ward is designed around a reminiscence theme, with things from the forties, fifties and sixties which is what our patients are familiar with. We have different areas within the ward which helps people remember their environment and it aides them remembering their environment. We've got a room designed like a woodshed which has got potting plants which helps some of our men who are used to that kind of activity. We've also got a kitchen which is based around the themes of the 1950s so relatives and their patients can sit there and have quality time. We've also got an area which is a hair salon which is where our female patients tend to congregate and it's just like when they used to visit the salon in the fifties.

The main areas of our ward are very open which gives people the ability to walk round in a big open space which helps alleviate their distress. This is also demarcated into a dining area, living room area, theres a sensory area where people can just spend time getting familiar with different smells, textures and all these things have been shown to alleviate the distress.

The design of the ward is based on work from Stirling University, Bradford University and The Kings Fund which shows that if you modify people's environment it can help with the behaviours associated with advanced dementia which is what we are trying to promote.

Brian and Mary (Patient and Carer)

Brian:

I'm Brian, Im 79, just (2 days ago!), I live with my wife Mary. Weve both had professional careers. I'm the one with dementia and she's (Mary) my carer.

Mary:

Im Mary and I am Brians carer, as hes mentioned. It's been a bit of an adventure over the past few years, but we'll discuss more about that in a minute.

After Diagnosis:

Brian:

I had a stroke about seven years ago and I began to realise that my short term memory was going and I have experience of dementia because my parents both had dementia at quite young ages. My long term memory was OK and I talked with the doctor and various other people and we realised that I had early onset dementia (early stages of dementia) and therefore we didn't know what it was exactly, I wasn't unduly worried except for the fact that it might have got worse quickly and that concerned me because what was the effect going to be on the family?

Mary:

Well, I think as far as I was concerned I was quite relieved as I know that Brian was really quite worried about what was happening to him. And once you actually know you can then face what the diagnosis is and so once we knew we could then look forward to what was going to happen next, whether it was going to be slow, whether it was going to be quick, or whatever, it didnt really matter. We knew and I think knowing what something is, is always the most important thing.

Brian:

When we first realised I had got dementia, we talked with the GP and various other people as well to establish what sort of dementia I had got. I had various things like a CT scan at local hospitals, I had a whole session of hospitals and I talked with professionals as well. It does help the fact that one of my sisters-in-law is a health professional and I was a good case study as far as she was concerned and she was able to give me some information. She also told me to swim again, that was good as well!

But we sort out what sort of strategies we both of us needed to do to make sure that the dementia was in control, we'll never control it totally, but in control. For example, when Mary realised that I couldn't cook anymore with any safety, she took over the cooking and realising that I couldn't fill in forms, so she took over filling in the forms.

Mary:

I think for Brian it was really quite frustrating, (Yes, Brian agrees) because having been a professional chemist and running a laboratory and all those things, to actually not be able then to be in control, although he was obviously retired, of the things he wanted to do, was quite a hard lesson for him to learn. I had to be quite careful that although I was able to take over many of those things it's quite difficult if you're the person with the disability, sitting there watching somebody else do it when you used to be able to do yourself. Brian no longer can do sort of maintenance around the place so, I'm putting new lightbulbs in, screwing up shelves, all those sorts of things that Brian no longer can do, but I have to say to him that he can do all sorts of things still!

Accepting the Diagnosis

Mary:

Yes, I think it is very important that you do accept the diagnosis, rather than sometimes people want to deny it. And we actually have friends who we explain the situation to and they still deny the fact that Brian has dementia. And I find that a little bit hard to take because it has been proven that he has got dementia. I accepted it from the start because I feel that is the way to go forward. If you are in denial of something you are not actually facing up to it and facing something is a positive thing and you can then go forward from that point planning the way in which your life is going to be from now onwards. Life hasn't finished with dementia not by a long, long way. Life with dementia is different but it can be very fulfilling!

Living with Dementia

Mary:

Also, of course, you need to have support from family, which is great, but you don't want to rely on your family all the time, make sure they are kept fully informed of the situation, but at the same time use other agencies which are available. We are really fortunate in Bexley because there is a carer's hub that you can go to, to get information. It's just a case of linking into these things, theres Oomph! which is an armchair exercise which we go to for dementia people, you meet friends there, you can chat with them. There's dementia cafes, all sorts of things where you can go. Please don't stay indoors and just think you've got to deal with it by yourself, because that's not the way it is these days, there are lots of different activities that you can link into.

The only thing I would say is don't cram the week with something every day, otherwise your patient, your dementia partner, will get absolutely worn out (Brian agrees: Yes!) and not be able to cope! You really do need to space them out, two or three things perhaps, during the week, or a ride out into the country, just to keep, not just your patient going, but yourself as well. You really do need to be able to have different things to do, rely on neighbours, we've got brilliant neighbours, who are ready to help out - one takes Brian to a club theres all sorts of things that you just can link in to so that youre not just sitting indoors.

Brian:

I try and keep my mind active, I watch television, I read the newspaper, I read books, magazines, I talk with people, as you realise, I can talk for England! All those things are quite important, I keep my mind as active as I can.

Mary and I like singing, now, one of the off-shoots of the dementia cafe is that they sing, there's a singing group. Unfortunately, the sort of music they sing, I don't like!ÃÂ  I'm much more classically inclined, but at our church, there is a rock choir, it's not part of the church, it just meets there, and we're thinking of joining them this spring.

Mary:

Basically, you have to try, in some little way, to put something in place of those things that you can't do. Not necessarily, the same sort of thing but if you can think of something else somebody can do, even if it just a small thing that they get a sense of achievement doing.

Now Brian doesn't like playing games! I think it is because he always used to like to win! If it is something that he doesn't understand and he's not going to win, that can be difficult! The other evening we played Rummikub and by the end Brian was getting it really really well. Although at the beginning he wondered (turning to Brian) what you were doing (Brian: I wondered what I was up to!), but that was an achievement and that's been put in place of something that perhaps he can't do now. I'm going to make sure he plays some more of those games now as well!

Coping as a carer

Mary:

There are lots of different ways in which you can help yourself as a carer, one of them is to get some support from lots of different people, one of them would be your neighbours, we've got very good neighbours who will help out and take Brian out and take him to clubs. There's also family, obviously you don't want to put upon your family all the time but they're very often very willing if only you ask and they'll take the patient out or you can all go out together, it just spreads the load. Also there are various agencies that you can enjoy, you can go to armchair exercises, you can go to dementia cafes together. And we have a carer who comes in once a fortnight and looks after Brian while I go off with friends or even by myself to do a lot of retail therapy and have lunches out and Brian gets really concerned that I know more about the pubs in Kent than he does!

You see, the thing is, a carer who is happy and relaxed and has space, is a good carer. If you spend all your time with your patient then you can become overwhelmed and it's very good to make sure that you don't get to that stage, but instead spread the load, don't feel guilty, make sure that you have that help that is required and then you'll find that life becomes so much easier.

Brian:

At least once a year, Mary goes away for nearly a week with a friend from the church. That's good because she goes away, they go crazy, they go to various places like Warners or somewhere like that. And that's a good break for her, I have Mary's brother who comes and looks after me which is rather nice and we have a good time together and Mary has a good time too!

Lastly:

Mary:

One of the things to remember that life is going to be different, because your patient has a different way of processing things, but just because it's different it doesn't mean it's not fulfilling. Make sure you do things that you can both enjoy and you'll find that life is fulfilling even if it's different.

Thank you to Brian and Mary!

content.name: title
content.content: LHIS Developer README

content.name: html_40
content.content:
Create Application

Create a New application using Copy from the main Infinity app page

If using DOS setup data within DOS Azure DB:

  • Connect to Azure server crmteam.database.windows.net using SSMS

  • Connect to DB YOD

  • Add a new row to table [dbo].[app] reference format of existing records to determine format of new

  • For each service entry you need to add a row to table [dbo.servicedirectory]

  • The [dbo.servicedirectory] table holds all rows for all LHIS apps that use DOS, so you need to add to rather than overwrite

  • You can also make use of bulk load facilities if you are familiar with SSMS

  • The [dbo.servicedirectory] table holds all rows for all LHIS apps that use DOS, so you need to add to rather than overwrite

  • Field [servicedirectory_id] is unique so you will need to increment for each row, some fields are mandatory so you wont be able to save the row if not populated

  • Follow the same format as other rows within the DB, ensure [category_id] and [region_id] is populated

  • Tables [dbo.region] and [dbo].[organisationtype] can be updated

  • For each new row you enter in the table [dbo.servicedirectory] you MUST to add a row to the [dbo].[app_servicedirectory_map] table

  • Field [mapping_id] is unique for each row, [app_id] will be the id of the app from point 4, [servicedirectory_id] will be the id of the new DOS entry you have created

    • Change app name within DOS api calls:

  • Navigate to pages

  • Select directory page

  • Within item 'scrollable_1' click 'button_1' then 'Actions tab' set the app name to the name of the app defined within the DOS DB

  • Navigate to 'App config' then 'Integration'

  • Select 'servicedirec' asset

  • Select 'Operations tab'

  • Double click 'app' parameter

  • Change Default app name to the name of the app defined within the DOS DB

    • Change Geo location of Organisation app has been built for:

  • Navigate to App config

  • Open function 'getLocation'

  • Set long and latitude - find using http://postcodes.io/

    • Set App Logo(s):

  • Ensure the new app logo is saved with name 'appLogoLeft' or 'appLogoRight' (i.e appLogoLeft.jpg)

  • Overwrite asset 'imgAppLogoLeft' or 'imgAppLogoRight' by deleting existing image and selecting New File

  • Copy content of 'theme_1' CSS asset into Notepad++

  • Search for '#title_bar{' and ensure styling is ok for header of app including size of new logo(s), if only one right hand logo is being used you can remove

    • reference to the left ensuring you also remove the comma between each CSS reference

  • Copy the CSS back to 'theme_1' within Infinity and test

    • Set Header Logo:

  • Ensure the new app logo is saved with name 'headLogo' (i.e headLogo.jpg)

  • Overwrite asset 'imgHeadLogo' by deleting existing image and selecting New File

  • Copy content of 'theme_1' CSS asset into Notepad++

  • Search for '.homeheading{' and ensure styling is ok for header of app including size of new logo

  • Copy the CSS back to 'theme_1' within Infinity and test

    • Set Application Colour:

  • Use the web to find the RGB value of the required background if you do not already have it

  • Copy content of 'theme_1' CSS asset into Notepad++

  • Search for the classes below and replace the existing RGB colour with the new within 'theme_1'

    • a{ class - on row 6 requires hex colour value

    #homescrollable{

    #select_1{

    #select_2{

    #static_2{

    .homemenuapp{

    .content-block h2{

    .content-block h3{

    .homemenu{

    .footercontainer{

    .contentlink{

    .livinglink{ - THEN colour: VARIABLE

    .directoryitem{ - THEN colour: VARIABLE

    ul.dropdown-menu li a{

  • Copy the CSS back to 'theme_1' within Infinity and test

    • Video(s):

  • Ensure the new app videos are saved with name vid_a, vid_b. vid_c etc. (i.e vid_a.mp4)

  • Overwrite assets 'vid_a' etc by deleting existing video and selecting New File

  • Test

    • Page Image(s):

  • Ensure the new app images are saved with name 'img_' + page name + app short name i.e. img_home_YOD img_finances_OXL etc. (i.e img_working_OXL.jpg)

  • Add new image with new New File

  • Test

    • Content:

    Work with defined App Map to ensure pages, headings, subheadings and content is updated
